David Fincher has always been slightly left of centre. It's easy to see why he was so drawn to the Alien franchise in the beginning, with its gothic stylings and absolute subversion of sci-fi and horror tropes, and while Alien 3 didn't quite turn out the way anyone particularly hoped, Fincher has consistently chosen films which have found a way to play on our expectations in new and interesting ways. Se7en's finale, Fight Club's central premise, Zodiac's long and twisting narrative that just refuses to resolve itself to our timeframe; all of these and so many more examples point to exactly the kind of filmmaker that David Fincher has proven himself to be, and he revels in the chance to walk that tightrope with audiences.

Up to a certain point in Gone Girl, I was initially confused by Fincher's choice of story here. It presents itself as a by the book thriller, and while it's executed in a downright pristine way with Fincher's work, it made absolutely no sense to me that the director who chose to direct The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo would also choose to direct something I'd seen a hundred times before.

And then of course he decides to rip the rug out from under everyone's feet.

When Amy Elliott Dunne goes missing, her husband Nick is at the front of the search and the investigation, as he tries to find his wife and to keep the law from finding him guilty of her murder.

It's a twist that's not necessarily unforeseeable, but it's delivered with such relish by Fincher and the performers involved that it's difficult not to imagine them sitting amongst an audience seeing it for the first time just giggling at everyone's reactions. And it's a credit to Fincher's patience that the shock hits home as well as it does, as he calmly sets up the first third of the movie without any sort of hint of what specifically is in store for the viewer. The precision and clinical feel of Fincher's direction up to this point plays to the conventions of the genre in a way that also feels like it's really all the film has to offer. It's a clever way to set up a twist, as it has half the audience writing the film off as a by-the-numbers thriller up until a third of the way through the film. The later two-thirds feel like uncharted territory as a result, and Fincher plays with genre and their conventions in cleverly carefree ways; navigating thriller, horror, drama and comedy with the kind of ease that only a director with his kind of experience and confidence can. Every scene offers up something new and clever, and Fincher's dissection of each scene and the way he finds the layers beneath the film's outer surface brings a popcorn film up to some seriously impressive levels.

The main two characters of the film are Nick and Amy, and it's both impressive and unusual to see two characters written so well on each side of the story. Usually a villain is left too one-dimensional or a hero is just too bland for the story, but both Nick and Amy are layered, interesting characters, each of them with so much to do throughout the film's runtime. And each of them have their perfect human counterparts in Ben Affleck and Rosamund Pike. Affleck has been steadily building a new reputation for himself with The Town and his all conquering Argo, but both of those were directed by him as well, and it's interesting to see him in a role where he isn't directly involved in the behind the scenes processes of directing or writing on this one. He's fantastic as Nick, and not in the kind of way where you're thanking the stars that it's not another Daredevil, it's the kind of performance that demands a lot of its performer and where that performer is absolutely up to the task. Affleck is so many things in this film, often at once, and he manages to pull off the trick of being a sympathetic asshole; a man who's being slowly backed into a corner and trying desperately to avoid lashing out in case it's misinterpreted as the actions of a lunatic. You can feel the presence of electronic eyes in all of his performance, and the fact that a 24-hour news cycle can contribute to a man's innocence or guilt drives a lot of Affleck's ambiguity when it comes to pinning down just whether he's done the deed or not. The villainous chin so often referenced in the movie actually nails the idea of Affleck's character needing to be both a possible villain and a character you can root for, and Affleck nails it. But as good as his performance is, it's always going to play second fiddle to Rosamund Pike's breakout brilliance as Amy Elliott Dunne. She picked up the film's only Oscar nomination and it's no surprise, as she brings an effortless reality to a role that could so easily fall into caricature, finding humour and likeability in a role that can't have been easy to find any. She has so many different roles to play within this one character and it's fascinating to see the amount of information she can pack into one expression. There's a moment towards the end of the film when she stares down Kim Dickens' Detective which is so simple and so effective that it could be a summation of her character's entire role. But that would be limiting; her performance is so smart and has so much range that it's difficult to nail one defining moment. The supporting players elevate the performance beyond these two phenomenal leads as well, with Kim Dickens and Carrie Coon bringing brains and heart in their performances and Tyler Perry giving what is easily the best performance of his career.

The book's author Gillian Flynn adapted Gone Girl for the screenplay, and while I haven't read the book it's impressive to see the kind of detail and smarts involved in the script, as well as just how well balanced the entire movie is. It's paced perfectly, and the way it moves from section to section builds to some truly impressive scenes towards the end of the film. There are some fantastic quotes to find here and the recurring themes and quotes that Flynn plays with introduces an entirely new selection of phrases to the national lexicon. But mostly it's the way that these characters are handled and explored throughout the film that makes this screenplay so impressive.

Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross continue their fantastic collaboration with David Fincher and this score could be their best one yet, as they create a subtly rotting world of cotton candy in their tracks. You can feel the slight shift from normality to not quite there throughout the film and their contribution is a huge reason that the film works on these themes as well as it does.

Occasionally a brilliant director can take popcorn entertainment and turn it into art. Spielberg did it with Jaws in 75 and Fincher has done it again with Gone Girl. It's a brilliant film that creates a new standard for the genre and a cultural phenomenon in the process.

Once disappeared. Now found. Here's my take on GONE GIRL (2014).

There have been numerous films that deal with the intricate facets of marriage; mostly set on a very positive tone. Sometimes the road leads to the unconventional yet entertaining or veers to the rudimentary yet real. But it truly fascinates me when it gears toward a sicker and more twisted approach that only exceptional directors can fully realize.

One notable example who's willing to take the driver's seat is Oscar nominee David Fincher. With the bold script from author-turned-screenwriter Gillian Flynn, Fincher takes us on a journey to the darker avenues of the so-called "married life".

Ben Affleck and Rosamund Pike play husband and wife (Nick and Amy Dunne) trapped in a life of ups and downs. Amid the game of bondage, Nick's life will turn into great degrees upon the disappearance of his better half. Trouble ensues. Deception surfaces. Madness arrives. And it gets darker from there.

This faithful adaptation of the best-selling novel stems from the team's vision of redefining everyone's thought on "Marriage"- IT'S NOT AS FREAKING EASY AS IT SEEMS. The film's never afraid to re-examine the very dynamics of human relationship and spew fires of the ugly truths that come with it.

Affleck has greatly elevated his leading man status while Pike has finally become a household name. They are so effective that their onscreen chemistry can shift from likable to dangerous. The rest of the cast (from Neil Patrick Harris to Tyler Perry to Carrie Coon to Kim Dickens to Missi Pyle etc.) strongly supports from start to finish.

Wise decision indeed, Fincher relies on his highly formidable team- haunting music supplied by Nine Inch Nail's Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross / sharp editing maneuvered by Kirk Baxter/ and precise cinematography focused by Jeff Cronenweth- the same people who gave life to gems like "The Social Network" and "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo".

This film is not to be missed. Just leave all the expectations at your door and enjoy the bumpy road ahead. Even if it means enduring a chaotic ride.

rt_summary: In Carthage, Mo., former New York-based writer Nick Dunne (Ben Affleck) and his glamorous wife Amy (Rosamund Pike) present a portrait of a blissful marriage to the public. However, when Amy goes missing on the couple's fifth wedding anniversary, Nick becomes the prime suspect in her disappearance.
